2. Knowing that matter is made out of atoms might give the average person a worse understanding (in a practical sense) of the natural world because the legibility gives them comfort to stop thinking about the structure of things amd how they come to be. Their thinking linearizes.

3. Atoms are sort of like the parameters to a software languave in a universe with a single language. You need to know what they are, but once you start building it becomes more important how these informatic kernels are being applied.

What users see:

4. 'Atoms' is the language of enthusiasts and charlatans. It often comes with the idea that if we could *just* get more of these atoms we really like, great things would happen. Interactions and complexity are ignored, but the Thiel-style marketing works even while funding DTC.

5. I initially drew a blank with this prompt because I don't think much about atoms. They're not all that interesting.

We can see individual photons, but when has an individual atom ever gone out of its way to do something for you?

6. 256 bits of entropy gives plenty of security. Take a polymer where you can get rotations in each position along the chain and consider that the molecules can have far more than 256 mers. What does your atom tell you now?

7. But that's getting away from opinion and moving toward observation. Can't make this too easy.

8/ Materials and processes where it might be optimal to have some atom, but it is entirely possible to swap it out for a different atom.

That this shifts to a business economics domain should make it no less interesting from a technical perspective...

9. Between atoms and the real world from a human perspective there are many layers. Hierarchical models sometimes smear these layers.

It ends with economics, but that is itself a thermodynamic process so at the highest level we return to the foundations.

10. This is not just abstract nonsense. Scientists are not particularly fond of atoms either and prefer pretending they don't exist.

Even a single atom gets ignored with the electron wavefunction simplified in DFT to have the slightest chance of a model that can be computed.

11. If you want to model your atom-based stuff in a less lossy way, you don't have many options.

Tinkering in ways that look unsophisticated to outside observers are one though.

12. Tinkering is still the best way to improve what you can get from your atoms, despite all the people who want you to focus on machine learning & sophisticated analytic lab tech.

Tinkering is a perfect simulation, but it's an illegible process that VC's don't know how to fund.

16. The atom is viewed as the opposite end point of the macro-world, but since it is a continuum that wraps around through thermodynamics of life itself, there are no end points. It is just as valid to call 0 the middle of the real numbers as 5,837.

17. The field of materials became an offshoot of metallurgical engineering, which itself came about to intermediate the mechanical engineers from the chemists and physicists.

This might be at the core of the pervasive myth that materials actually exist.
18. I suspect the definitiveness of atoms brings people solace in a confusing and uncertain world.
19. A material though, is a somewhat arbitrary set of layers in the stack of the physical world that disconnects from its atomic composition.

20. But these 'materials' decouple from themselves in the real world. Locally, they seem consistent and well-behaved, but they decouple from themselves at ordinary macroscopic scales. This is why a thread of spider silk cannot stop a Boeing 737, no matter how long you make it.

21. So materials do not have an 'atomic'-like consistency. Particles, atoms, and matter are all real.

Materials is an abstraction not grounded in physics, with little more fundamentality than real-world structures. (Structures can be precise when considered mathematically)

22. I started this thread narrowly considering what an atom is, but there are other things atomic beyond what you'll find on the periodic table.

An atom is merely a well-defined fungible encapsulation of something.

31. It is easier to impose structure in more of a top-down fashion. Then afterwards, if you're curious, you can ask the scientists what the atoms are up to.

This is why the machines should come first.

32. As machines become more capable of manipulating atoms in large groups of atoms that are not being thought about as atoms, there will be a transition toward software-driven processes.

The software and resultant structure will dictate performance.

34. Most of the time you'd be better off building more at the macro-scale than going back to evaluate minutia of your atoms.
